{{inline|date=November 2018}}{{onesource|date=November 2018}} [[Image:VictoriaBridgeHotelDamascus.jpg|thumb|right|300px|The Victoria Bridge and Hotel over the River [[Barada]] in the 1870s. The Victoria Hotel in Damascus, the largest tourist hotel in Syria at the time was owned by Abid]] '''Ahmad Izzat Basha Al-Abed''' (1851 - 1924) (أحمد عزت العابد) was a [[Syria|Syrian]] [[politician]].
Abid was born in [[Damascus]], but he was educated in [[Beirut]]. He spoke [[Arabic]], [[French language|French]] and [[Turkish language|Turkish]]. He moved to [[Istanbul]] where he served the [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] sultan, [[Abdul Hamid II]] as an adviser. He left the Ottoman Empire in 1908 and moved to [[London]] for some time before living in [[France]] and [[Switzerland]]. He then left for [[Egypt]], where he died in 1924.
Abid accumulated great wealth during his life. He was also a businessman and owned numerous enterprises or buildings including the largest tourist hotel in Syria, the Victoria Hotel in Damascus.
He was the father of [[Mohammed Ali Bay al-Abid]], who served as [[List of Presidents of Syria|president of Syria]] from 11 June 1932 until 21 December 1936.
== Bibliography == *{{cite book |last=Commins |first=David Dean |date=2004 |title=" Abid, Ahmad Izzat al- (1851-1924) ", Historical Dictionary of Syria |url=https://books.google.fr/books?hl=fr&id=_EhACvcqVXkC&dq=%22Ahmad+Izzat+al-Abid%22&q=%22ABID%2C+AHMAD+IZZAT+AL-+%281851-1924%29%22#v=snippet&q=%22ABID%2C%20AHMAD%20IZZAT%20AL-%20%281851-1924%29%22&f=false |publisher=Scarecrow Press |edition=2nd |page=21-22 |isbn=9780810849341 |access-date= }}

{{more footnotes|date=May 2012}} '''Akhat (Alexander) Khafizovich (Sergeevich) Bragin''' ({{lang-uk|Ахать (Олександр) Хафізович (Сергійович) Брагін}}, {{lang-ru|Ахать (Александр) Хафизович (Сергеевич) Брагин}}, {{lang-tt|Әхәт (Александр) Хафиз улы Брагин}}; 1953 — October 15, 1995) was an [[Ukraine|Ukrainian]] businessman of [[Volga Tatars|Volga Tatar]] descent. He was a mafia figure of the [[Donetsk Oblast]] and later the president of the football club [[FC Shakhtar Donetsk|Shakhtar Donetsk]] until his death.
==Biography== Akhat Hafizovich Bragin was born in 1953 in the [[Kuibyshevskyi Raion]] of [[Donetsk]] city, [[Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic|Ukrainian SSR]]. Before he became the president of [[FC Shakhtar Donetsk|Shakhtar Donetsk]], he was also a [[butcher]] at a local market in Oktyabrsky Raion.
==Education== Donetsk Institute of Soviet Trading (today Donetsk National University of Economy and Trading), dropout.
==Convictions== * November 24, 1971 – convicted (the Criminal Code of Ukraine) by the Kuibyshev District Court of Donetsk to a conditional year of imprisonment with correctional term of 2 years without confiscation of property
==Personal life== Bragin had a wife and two children: Dilyara (1985—2009) and Ravil (b. 1989).
==Assassination and attempts== An attempt to kill Bragin took place on March 19, 1994, at a settlement called [[Pisky, Yasynuvata Raion|Pisky]] (Bragin's hometown). [[Pisky, Yasynuvata Raion]] is a rural settlement of [[Yasynuvata Raion]], just to the west from the [[Donetsk International Airport]]. A group of bandits from the Ryabin-Kushnir gang (run by Yevhen Kushnir and Anatoliy Ryabi) opened fire on Bragin's pigeon house. Miraculously Akhat Bragin survived the attempt.
Akhat Bragin died in a bomb attack on Sunday, October 15, 1995, at the [[Shakhtar Stadium (Donetsk)|Shakhtar Stadium]] in Donetsk. After this event, the new president and chairman of Shaktar Donetsk became [[Rinat Akhmetov]]. The reason for Akhat's murder was his business dealings. Known in the criminal underworld as 'Alik the Greek', his organization got into conflict with several others. The investigation into his death made little progress until the confession of a rival gangster, which led to the arrest and imprisonment of former policeman Vyacheslav Synenko.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/akhat-bragin-31849.html Kyiv Post - Akhat Bragin]</ref>
==Legacy== In honor of Akhat Bragin, the mosque of Donetsk is called [[Ahat Jami Mosque, Donetsk|Ahat Jami]].
==See also== * [[Yevhen Shcherban]] * [[Janos Kranz]]
==References== {{reflist}}

True Story of the oligarch] * [http://www.bbc.co.uk/ukrainian/domestic/story/2004/03/040330_bragin_donetsk.shtml The name of Bragin is still remembered in Donetsk] * [http://genshtab.censor.net.ua/wiki/%D0%91%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B3%D0%B8%D0%BD,_%D0%90%D1%85%D0%B0%D1%82%D1%8C_%D0%A5%D0%B0%D1%84%D0%B8%D0%B7%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B8%D1%87 Akhat Bragin on the website genshtab] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20130214070629/http://sprava.civicua.org/donetskie/do002donwars.html ''Donetsk Wars. Episode 1'']. "Panorama weekly". 2002-06-12.

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2018}} {{More citations needed|date=October 2018}}{{Infobox company |name = Bandini Automobili |company_slogan = |logo = Bandini automobili.JPG |logo_size = 150px |foundation = 1946 |location_city = [[Forlì]] |location_country = [[Italy]] |key_people = [[Ilario Bandini|Eng. H.C. Ilario Bandini]], founder |area_served = |industry = [[Automobile]] |products = [[Sports cars]] |parent = |type = Defunct (1992) |homepage = [http://www.ilariobandini.it www.ilariobandini.it]
[http://www.bandinicars.com www.bandinicars.com] |footnotes = }} ''' Bandini Automobili''' was an [[Italy|Italian]] automobile manufacturer operating between 1946 and 1992. It was named after its founder [[Ilario Bandini]]. Founded in 1946 in Bandini’s hometown [[Forlì]], the first Bandini used a modified [[Fiat 1100 (1937)|Fiat 1100]] engine, the body was made from hand hammered aluminum and the chassis from aviation-grade tubular steel. Many other post-war Italian sports car companies followed a similar design. But Bandini’s sharp mind, racing knowledge and his eye for detail ensured that Bandini cars were a force to be reckoned with in Europe and the US. Interest in America surged when Bandini Siluros, with their screaming 750-cc engines and wildly flared front fenders, won [[SCCA]] class championships in 1955 and 1957. His slightly modified Crosley engines became famous thanks their [[DOHC]] Bandini heads. Bandini himself continued to race in Italy, including the [[Mille Miglia]], while newer models were being built and developed at the factory. One of these included the new 1957 Sport International [[Bandini_750_sport_internazionale|"Saponetta"]]. It was a two-seat sports car with a tubular steel frame and room for engines of up to 1.0 liter. The design of the car body was very striking. The smooth lines and petite dimensions gave the car the Italian nickname "Saponetta" (little soap). The [[Bandini formula 3|Formula 3]] car of 1954{{Citation needed|date=January 2010}} had disc brakes on all four wheels, following closely on the 1951 [[Jaguar C-Type|C-type Jaguar]]. The [[Zagato]] bodied Bandini GT raced in Daytona and [[12 Hours of Sebring]]. The coupé by Corna was a 1000 cc and the engine was mounted in front. [[File:Depliant Bandiniautomobili.JPG|thumb|150px|left]] [[File:Bandinicollection.jpg|thumb|150px|left|'''Bandini Collection''']] [[File:Bandini day Forlì 2002.JPG|thumb|150px|left|'''Bandini Day, 2002''']] ==Racing history== {{See also|Ilario Bandini}} Ilario divided his time between design and manufacturing of the cars, and as a race driver. He entered and drove his cars in more than 60 races, both [[Hillclimbing|hillclimb]] events and track racing, including the Mille Miglia from 1947 until 1965, achieving 19 first-place finishes and 18 podiums in the 750cc and 1000cc classes. In the United States, Bandini cars won the [[SCCA]] HM class championship in 1955{{cite web|url=http://www.ferrariexperts.com/SCCA%20results%201955.htm#SCC|title=SCCA Results 1955|accessdate=1 June 2014}} thanks to driver Dolph Vilardi. In 1957 Melvin Sachs won the HM class,{{cite web|url=http://www.ferrariexperts.com/SCCA%20results%201957.htm#SCC|title=SCCA Results 1957 |accessdate=1 June 2014}} one of five Bandini's in the first ten positions. The successes resulted in Ilario being presented with the Gold Key of Daytona and later in 1981 the Laurea H.C. award in mechanical engineering from PRODEO university of New York. In 1959 he produced one of the most successful [[Formula_Junior|Formula Juniors]]. Bandinis won SCCA Class HMod races well into the mid-1960s. A [[Bandini_1100_siluro|Bandini Siluro]] won the SCCA Southwest Regional Championship from 1961–1963 and the Saponetta took 3rd place in the National Hmod class in 1961. Bandini continued to make one-off cars well into the 1980s. Ilario, sometimes known as the "great Drake of Forli" died in 1992. ==Memorial to Ilario Bandini== [[File:Bandini square.JPG|thumb|150px|right|'''Dedication to the great Ilario Bandini''']] [[File:Bandinibook.jpg|thumb|right|150px|'''Cover of the book, authors Franco Fabbri and Cesare Sangiorgi.''']] On 16 November 2002 the city of Forlì, Italy remembered Ilario Bandini who is considered one of the most important Italian constructors of performance sports and race cars. The city dedicated a plaza (town square) to honor his name and the racing cars that bear his name. ==Bandini Museum and Register== Since 1992, in Bandini's last workshop, Ilario's family has preserved all documents and collected the most representative cars for display. Ten Bandinis are in the museum and are shown by appointment. 46 Bandinis exist in the world today and are acknowledged by the Register. They are owned from the U.S. to Japan. ==Models== * [[Bandini 1100 (1946)|"La prima" 1100/46]] (1946) * [[Bandini 1100|1100 sport]] (1947–50) * [[Bandini 1100 siluro|1100 siluro]] (1947–49) * [[Bandini 750 sport siluro|750 sport siluro]] (1950–56) * [[Bandini-Maserati 1500]] (1952) * [[Bandini formula 3|formula 3]] (1954–58) * [[Bandini GT|berlinetta Zagato]] (1955) * [[Bandini 750 sport internazionale|750 sport internazionale "saponetta"]] (1957–61) * [[Bandini formula junior|formula junior]] (1959–62) * [[Bandini 1000 P|1000/62 P]] (1962–65) * [[Bandini 1000 GT|1000 GT]] (1963) * [[Bandini 1000|1000/66 sport]] (1966) * [[Bandini saloncino|saloncino]] (1968) * [[Bandini 1000 V|1000/70 V]] (1970) * [[Bandini s.p. 1000|mille s.p.]] (1972) * [[Bandini 1300|1300 16 V i.]] (1980) * [[Bandini 1000 turbo|berlinetta 1000 turbo]] (1992) image:1100_siluroBandini.jpg image:Bandini750ssgara.jpg image:Bandini_Saponetta2.jpg image:hassen bandini.jpg image:Ilario_Bandini_motori.JPG {{Infobox book | name = Chief Culture Officer | image = | country = Canada | author = [[Grant McCracken]] | subject = Business Book | published = 2009 ([[Basic Books]] (HC)) | pages = 261 pp. | followed_by = Culturematic }} '''''Chief Culture Officer''''' (2009) is the eighth book by [[Canada|Canadian]] [[author]] and [[anthropologist]] [[Grant McCracken]].{{cite web|title=Psychology Today Profile|url=http://www.psychologytoday.com/experts/grant-mccracken-phd|publisher=[[Psychology Today]]|date=February 2005}} The book looks at how modern business attempt to connect with culture. In the author's analysis he considers examples such as [[Dove Campaign for Real Beauty|Dove's campaign for real beauty]], and the [[I Love New York]] advertising campaign. According to McCracken, the book is about highlighting the importance of modern culture for businesses, and in doing so, to create a position within them for a "person who knows culture, both its fads and fashions, and its deep, enduring structures": a Chief Culture Officer.{{cite book |last=McCracken |first=Grant |year=2009 |title=Chief Culture Officer |location=P.2 |publisher=Basic Books |isbn=978-0-465-02204-5}} == Synopsis == In the book, McCracken recounts how corporations that successfully adapt to the cultural changes tend to prosper. His definition of [[culture]] begins with a distinction between fast and slow:
"Fast culture is like all the boats on the surface of the Pacific. We can spot them, track them. Slow culture is everything beneath the surface: less well charted, much less visible"{{cite book |last=McCracken |first=Grant |year=2009 |title=Chief Culture Officer |location=P.44 |publisher=Basic Books |isbn=978-0-465-02204-5}}
McCracken argues that when fast and slow culture meet, a convergent culture is created. He points to the [[preppy]] subculture as an example of a convergent culture that brands such as [[Ralph Lauren]] and [[Tommy Hilfiger]] have capitalized on. He also analyses the convergence of [[Social status|status]], shifting from a class based value system to celebrity, and the [[cool (aesthetic)|cool]] convergence, an aesthetic that he states developed alongside the [[baby boomer]] generation. Changing relationships, McCracken argues, between consumers and producers have created new opportunities for brands to connect with culture. He observes that whilst only [[1% rule (Internet culture)|1 in 100]] people create content on the Internet, the creator consumer dynamic used to be "1 in 10,000". McCracken believes this change allows consumers to become an "active participant in the branding process". He refers to [[converse (shoe company)|Converse's]] 2005 motto as an illustration of this change:
"We don't own the brand. Consumers do"{{cite book |last=McCracken |first=Grant |year=2009 |title=Chief Culture Officer |location=P.90 |publisher=Basic Books |isbn=978-0-465-02204-5}}
For business's attempting to closely monitor culture, McCracken advises against employing "cool hunters" who "know only what suits them." Instead, he recommends creating a position for a Chief Culture Officer who is aware of both fast and slow culture, a "creature of many worlds, captives of none."{{cite book |last=McCracken |first=Grant |year=2009 |title=Chief Culture Officer |location=P.190 |publisher=Basic Books |isbn=978-0-465-02204-5}} == Reception == [[Harvard Business Review]] recommended the book in their 2010 magazine, stating "a CCO is necessary for any competitive, consumer-oriented company".Bell, Catherine. [http://hbr.org/2010/01/recommended/ar/1 Recommended Books] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140122213032/http://hbr.org/2010/01/recommended/ar/1 |date=January 22, 2014 }}. ''Harvard Business Review''. January, 2010. [[Bookforum|The Bookforum]], however, declared the book "no different from the management tomes that have preceded it".Connelly, Phoebe. [http://www.bookforum.com/inprint/016_04/4696 The Brand Plays On] ''Bookforum''. December, 2010. Since publication a number of corporations have created the position of Chief Culture Officer (CCO).Millis, Elinor. [http://news.cnet.com/Meet-Googles-culture-czar/2008-1023_3-6179897.html Meet Google's Culture Czar] ''CNET''. April 27, 2007.Robins,Debbie. [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/debbie-robins/chief-culture-officer-buy_b_4057655.html Chief Culture Officer Buys Success] ''Huffington Post''. October 10, 2013. Stacy Sullivan, the CCO for [[Google]], was appointed by [[Sergey Brin]] and [[Larry Page]] to "enhance and develop" the corporations cultureDubois, Shelley. [http://management.fortune.cnn.com/2012/07/30/chief-culture-officers/ The Rise Of The Chief Culture Officer] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140223085203/http://management.fortune.cnn.com/2012/07/30/chief-culture-officers/ |date=February 23, 2014 }} ''CNN Money''. July 20, 2012. Author and Advertising industry subject expert Lorraine Stewart has also advised Advertising agencies to appoint a CCO, to "create sustained competitive advantage and increase their own agency-brand value".Stewart, Lorraine. [http://adage.com/article/guest-columnists/ad-agencies-appoint-a-chief-culture-officer/149476/ Want to Retain Talent? Time to Appoint a Chief Culture Officer]. ''AdAge''. March 21, 2011. == See also == * [[Diderot Effect]] == References == {{reflist}} == External links == * [http://cultureby.com/ Culture By] Grant McCracken's blog * [http://www.getstoried.com/interview-grant-mccracken-041310/ Audio Interview On Chief Culture Officer] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iR8n78VhJes Video Interview: Grant McCracken on Corporations and Culture] * [http://www.entrepreneur.com/article/207002 Interview with Grant McCracken by Entrepreneur] * [https://www.aaaa.org/inventory/new-shoes-how-understanding-organizational-culture-improves-the-performance-of-the-advertising-agency-industry] [[Category:Business books]] [[Category:Anthropology]]

revision.text:
'''Clarence K. Moniba, Ph.D''' (born March 15, 1979) is a former [[Liberia]]n government official. He served as the youngest person in the country’s history to be named Minister of State without Portfolio, as well the Chairman of the Board of the Liberia Electricity Corporation. He was a Principal Advisor and Project Manager to the President of Liberia and a leading figure on infrastructure development in Liberia from 2014 – 2018. Dr. Moniba at various times also headed the Diaspora Engagement Unit, the Philanthropy Secretariat and the President’s Delivery Unit which oversaw implementation of priority projects. Moniba in previous roles has worked with the African Development Bank’s High Level Panel on Post Conflict & Fragile States, as well as the United Nations Post-2015 Development Agenda. He was awarded the national medal [[Knight Commander of the Most Venerable Order of Pioneers]] - which then President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf stated was for his outstanding and distinguished service in government.
Prior to his work in the Liberian government, Moniba was a professional American football player in the [[Arena League]] (2001–04). He is also the author of ''The Official Guidebook to a College Football Scholarship''
He was the victim of several [[Nigerian scam|419]] and fake lottery scams, which claimed that he was in possession of, and willing to trade millions of dollars in diamonds and African gold.<ref>[http://www.419scam.org/emails/2005-06/07/216997.35.htm "419" Scam – Advance Fee / Fake Lottery Scam], joewein.de LLC.</ref>
==Acting career==
Moniba performed lead football stunts in the movie ''[[Radio (disambiguation)|Radio]]'', where he made the game-winning diving touchdown catch for the home team T.L. Hanna High School. He also played a lead football stunt role in the movie ''[[Invincible (2006 film)|Invincible]]'' where he went up going against the main character [[Vince Papale]], played by [[Mark Wahlberg|Mark Walhberg]], and he appeared in several football action scenes of ''[[We Are Marshall]]''.
==Book Publications==
Moniba wrote [https://www.amazon.com/Official-Guidebook-College-Football-Scholarship/dp/1456898132 The Official Guidebook to a College Football Scholarship] which was published nationwide in the United States in 2011.
==Football career==
Moniba played his college football at [[New Mexico State University]] from 1999 to 2001. He went on to play for four years in the [[Arena Football League]] for the Carolina and [[New York (state)|New York]] organizations.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.nmstatesports.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=1900&ATCLID=3676799|title=Aggies in the Pros|website=New Mexico State University|language=en|access-date=2018-05-03}}</ref>
==Personal life==
Clarence is the youngest son of Liberia's former Vice President, [[Harry Moniba|Dr. Harry F. Moniba]], who served in that capacity from 1984 to 1990.
==Education==
Moniba earned his Ph.D from New Mexico State University where he graduated with a degree in Rhetoric and Professional Communications. His focus was on Intercultural and International Communications. He earned his master's degree in International Relations. His published thesis is entitled "Ethnic Exclusion in Government – A Case Study of the Republic of Liberia".
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.thenewdawnliberia.com/~thenewd1/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=7938:harry-monibas-son-challenges-government&catid=25:politics&Itemid=59 Edwin G. Genoway, Jr, "Harry Moniba’s Son Challenges Government"], ''The New Dawn'', February 27, 2013.
*[https://nmstatesports.com/news/2009/2/23/3676799.aspx/ Aggies in the Pros. New Mexico State University]
*[http://lecliberia.com/ The Liberia Electricity Corporation]
*[https://www.amazon.com/Official-Guidebook-College-Football-Scholarship/dp/1456898132/ The Official Guidebook to a College Football Scholarship]
{{authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Moniba, Clarence}} [[Category:1979 births]] [[Category:Liberian writers]] [[Category:Liberian male film actors]] [[Category:New Mexico State Aggies football players]] [[Category:New York Dragons players]] [[Category:Liberian expatriates in the United States]] [[Category:Liberian diplomats]] [[Category:Liberian businesspeople]]

{{refimprove|date=June 2017}} {{notability|date=June 2017}} {{Infobox book | image = Conversational Capital.jpg | name = Conversational Capital: How to Create Stuff People Love to Talk About | author = [[Bertrand Cesvet]]
[[Tony Babinski]]
[[Eric Alper]] | country = Canada | language = English | subject = [[Marketing]] | publisher = [[Pearson Education]] | release_date = August 7, 2008 | media_type = Print ([[Hardcover]]) | pages = 208 | isbn = 978-0-13-714550-8 | dewey= 658.8/27 22 | congress= HF5415.1255 .C47 2009 | oclc= 214935159 }} '''''Conversational Capital: How to Create Stuff People Love to Talk About''''' is a book about engineering word-of-mouth into brand experiences. Contrary to the conventional theories of [[mass marketing]] literature, which teach that one must scream something ten times to be heard once, the authors teach that because we are all [[Storytelling| social storytellers]], a product experience that is worthy of telling as one's own authentic story creates enormous brand capital in the form of meaningful and influential conversations. Developed by a trio of international brand architects, they share the insights behind their creative and strategic leadership for word-of-mouth success stories including [[Adidas]], [[Cirque du Soleil]], [[Red Bull]] & [[MGM Grand Las Vegas|MGM Grand]]. ==Overview== Based on their experiences with some of the world's recognized generators of word-of-mouth, the authors behind Conversational Capital began to realize that experiences had residual value—value that extended further than mere memories but instead resided in the realm of identity-shaping and storytelling. That is to say, when an experience was sufficiently powerful or transformative for an individual, they felt compelled to make the experience part of their own life story, and thereby propagate the story of the experience as part of their own (and now more exciting) identity. With this in mind, Bertrand Cesvet, Tony Babinski and Eric Alper began to deconstruct the antecedents to word-of-mouth. Invariably, they found that the elements that gave rise to the conversations of consumers consisted of eight possible drivers. Critically, these elements fed into doing two things for the experience in question: 1) making it meaningful and 2) making it intense. The authors of Conversational Capital share these eight key ingredients to embedding the makings of word-of-mouth into every consumer encounter with brands. They term these elements the Eight Engines of Conversational Capital. ===The Eight Engines=== '''1. Myths''' are the narratives that become part of the very fabric of consumption because they provide important clues as to fundamental meaning of that act. '''2. Rituals''' are an essential part of how human beings create and formalize meaning. The presence of ritual marks out an experience as deeper in meaning - a phenomenon that is true for consumer experiences, as well. '''3. Exclusive Product Offering (E.P.O.)''' is about allowing consumers to create an experience that asserts and actualizes their individuality; to, in a world of seven billion people, feel and be unique. '''4. Relevant Sensorial Oddity (R.S.O.)''' is about challenging our senses with something extraordinary, marking an experience as unique. '''5. Icons''' are signs and symbols that clearly demarcate a consumption experience from any other. '''6. Tribalism''' is about the power of a brand experience to inspire the association of like-minded people. '''7. Endorsement''' is not about celebrity — it's about how the meaning and intensity of a brand experience naturally lead to credible people organically endorsing it. '''8. Continuity''' is a strong harbinger of reputation, a fact that rests on the unity between what you promise, what people expect and what you deliver. The authors also recognize that Conversation Capital is nothing without conversational liquidity—the ability to share the stories as broadly as possible, and perhaps for this reason they frequently reference and recognize the [[Open Source]] movement and its way of creating connected communities that transcend geographic and other boundaries. == See also == * ''[[The Five Dysfunctions of a Team]]'' ==References== * [http://www.pearsonhighered.com/educator/academic/product/0,3110,0137145500,00.html ''Conversational Capital'' at Financial Times Press — A Pearson Imprint] ==External links== * [http://www.conversationalcapital.com/ Official Site] [[Category:2008 books]] [[Category:Marketing books]] [[Category:Business books]]

{{Unreferenced|date=January 2013}} {{marketing}} A '''Customer Advisory Council''' (also referred to as a '''Customer Advisory Board''' or '''CAB''') is a form of [[market research]] whereby a group of existing customers is convened on a regular basis to advise company management on industry trends, business priorities, and strategic direction. The CAB differs from traditional [[focus group]]s in the following ways:
* Membership is made up of senior executives from customer companies, not product users * Topics of discussion tend to be more strategic than tactical
== Composition == Customer advisory councils and CABs typically consist of 10 to 15 [[customers]] selected to represent a cross section of the customer base. Proper selection of attendees requires identifying not only the most strategic customer company, but also the proper individual who can best represent their company's needs, priorities, and directions. Key individuals who have a strong relationship with the sponsoring company and have valuable ideas to contribute are ideal candidates. Membership may also benefit from a few outspoken customers who have voiced strong complaints in the past about existing business practice.
== Frequency and format == It is common practice for customer advisory councils to meet 1-2 times per year. More frequent meetings are usually not practical due to time constraints of participants. Furthermore, it takes a significant amount of time to process the advisory council recommendations and implement them within the existing company strategy.
Meetings are usually held face-to-face for half a day or more. Meetings can also be held via [[teleconference]] or through interactive means though the level of 2-way dialogue may suffer. Meeting agendas usually leave ample time for facilitated discussion using a variety of brainstorming and workshop techniques.
== Council member expectations == Council members usually participate on a voluntary basis for the opportunity to influence company direction in a way which is beneficial to their own needs as well as the customer community. To maintain credibility it is important that the sponsors are committed to follow through on key recommendations made by the council or at minimum provide a rational explanation for those recommendations which are ultimately not implemented. Participants also typically benefit from the prestige of participation, ability to network with each other as well as with company officers, and opportunity to share best practices and new ideas.
== See also == * [[Focus group]] * [[Online research community]] * [[Observational techniques]]

{{Infobox company | name = Dole Food Company, Inc. | logo = Dole Logo.svg | type = [[Privately held company|Private]] | genre = | foundation = {{start date and age|1851|6|2}}[http://www.dole.com/CompanyInfo/About/History.jsp Dole: Company History] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071117163821/http://www.dole.com/CompanyInfo/About/History.jsp |date=November 17, 2007 }} (Retrieved November 29, 2007)

Other food products | services = | revenue = [[United States dollar|US $]]4.5 Billion (2016) [http://www.hoovers.com/dole-food/--ID__10303--/free-co-factsheet.xhtml Hoover's: Dole Food Company, Inc. Factsheet] (Retrieved April 2, 2012) | operating_income = | net_income = 38.4 million (2011) | num_employees = 34,500 (2011){{cite web|url=http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=259280 |title=Dole Food Company Inc.: Private Company Information - Businessweek |publisher=Investing.businessweek.com |date= |accessdate=2012-10-05}} | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | owner = | slogan = | homepage = {{URL|www.dole.com}} | dissolved = | footnotes = }} '''Dole Food Company, Inc.''' is an [[United States|American]] [[agricultural]] [[multinational corporation]] headquartered in [[Westlake Village, California]]. The company is the largest [[food industry|producer]] of [[fruit]] and [[vegetables]] in the world, operating with 74,300 full-time and seasonal employees who are responsible for over 300 products in 90 countries.{{cite web|url=http://biz.yahoo.com/ic/10/10303.html |title=Dole Food Company, Inc. Company Profile - Yahoo! Finance |publisher=Biz.yahoo.com |date=2012-09-25 |accessdate=2012-10-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130116165632/http://biz.yahoo.com/ic/10/10303.html |archivedate=2013-01-16 |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://www.hoovers.com/company/Dole_Food_Company_Inc/rfyfyi-1.html |title=| Company Profile from Hoover’s |publisher=Hoovers.com |date= |accessdate=2012-10-05}} Dole markets such food items as [[bananas]], [[pineapples]] (fresh and packaged), [[grapes]], strawberries, salads, and other fresh and frozen fruits and juices. Dole owns a shipping line, Dole Ocean Cargo Express. Dole's chairman founded the [[Dole Nutrition Institute]], a nutritional research and education foundation. ==History== [[Image:DolePineapplePlantation.jpg|thumb|left|Dole Plantation on [[Oahu, Hawaii]].]] The company traces its origin to the 1851 establishment of [[Castle & Cooke]] by missionaries [[Samuel Northrup Castle]] and [[Amos Starr Cooke]]. Castle & Cooke rapidly became one of the largest companies in Hawaii, investing in shipping, railroad construction, sugar production and seafood packing. The other half of Dole's corporate heritage, the '''Hawaiian Pineapple Company''', was founded in 1901 by [[James Dole]], who opened his first pineapple plantation in the central plateau of the Hawaiian island of [[Oahu]]. [[Sanford Dole]], the cousin of James, had been president of the [[Republic of Hawaii]] from 1894 after the [[overthrow of the Kingdom of Hawaii]] (her last monarch, [[Liliuokalani|Queen Lili{{okina}}uokalani]]), and first governor of the [[Territory of Hawaii]] until 1903.{{cite web |url= http://archives1.dags.hawaii.gov/gsdl/collect/governme/index/assoc/HASHb5a9/8f7a506f.dir/Dole,%20Sanford%20Ballard.jpg |title= Dole, Sanford Ballard office record |work= state archives digital collections |publisher= state of Hawaii |accessdate= 2010-01-20 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20120306203149/http://archives1.dags.hawaii.gov/gsdl/collect/governme/index/assoc/HASHb5a9/8f7a506f.dir/Dole%2C%20Sanford%20Ballard.jpg |archivedate= 2012-03-06 |df= }} The annexation of Hawaii to the United States made selling agricultural products to the mainland much more profitable, since they would never be subject to import [[tariff]]s. In 1932, Castle & Cooke purchased a 21% interest in the Hawaiian Pineapple Company. In the 1960s, Castle & Cooke acquired the remainder of the Hawaiian Pineapple Company and the [[Standard Fruit Company]]. In 1976, it acquired Bud Antle Inc., a California-based lettuce and celery farmer; it was renamed Dole Fresh Vegetables in 1989. The company was renamed "The Dole Food Company, Inc" in 1991. Castle & Cooke Inc, a [[real estate]] company, was spun off in 1995; it is currently operating as a subsidiary of Flexi-Van Leasing, Inc. Dole's [[Waialua Sugar Mill]] closed in 1996.{{Cite news| last = Star-Bulletin| first = Russ Lynch;| title = Waialua closing the book on Oahu's sugar industry - Today is the last day of harvesting and by Saturday the shutdown will be complete| work = Honolulu Star-Bulletin (HI)| accessdate = 2018-04-22| date = 1996-10-02| url = http://infoweb.newsbank.com/resources/doc/nb/news/1296CDE56F67D958?p=NewsBank|via=[[NewsBank]]}} Dole acquired Coastal Berry in 2004 and SunnyRidge Farms in 2011 to enter the berry business.[http://vegetablegrowersnews.com/news/dole-food-acquires-coastal-berry/ Dole Food Acquires Coastal Berry][http://www.growingproduce.com/uncategorized/dole-acquires-sunnyridge-farm/ Dole Acquires SunnyRidge Farm] [[File:Dole freighter in San Juan, Puerto Rico.jpg|thumb|200px|Dole freighter sailing out of [[San Juan, Puerto Rico]]]] It was then the third largest producer and U.S. importer of bananas. Dole and [[Chiquita]] remain the top two U.S. banana companies as of 2011. In 2011, the company reported $7.2 billion in annual [[revenue]]. Dole operates plantations throughout [[Central America|Central]] and [[South America]], and in the [[Asia-Pacific]] region, with plantations in the [[Philippines]] and two packing plants in [[Thailand]], [[Hua Hin]] and [[Chumphon]].{{cite web |url=http://www.dole.co.th/en/#contact-us |title=Locations of Dole Food Company in Thailand |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |year=2012 |work= |publisher=Dole Food Company |accessdate=9 September 2012}} As part of a major restructuring in 2012, Dole agreed to sell its worldwide packaged foods and Asian fresh produce businesses to Japanese trading house [[Itochu]] for $1.7 billion in cash. The transaction paid down a large amount of Dole's debt and refocused the company's business on fresh fruit and vegetables.{{cite web|title=Japan's Itochu to buy Dole Food businesses for $1.7 billion|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/09/18/us-dolefood-itochu-idUSBRE88H01L20120918|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=18 September 2012}} The businesses acquired by Itochu continue to use the Dole brand and are owned by Dole International Holdings, a Tokyo-based subsidiary of Itochu.{{cite web|title=Dole Business|url=http://www.itochu.co.jp/en/business/food/project/10/|publisher=Itochu Corporation|accessdate=2 September 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150908001600/http://www.itochu.co.jp/en/business/food/project/10/|archivedate=8 September 2015|df=}} In August 2013, Dole announced that CEO David Murdock would acquire the outstanding stock of the company for $1.2 billion.{{cite news | url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424127887323585604579008502351303672 | title=Dole Food Agrees to $1.2 Billion Buyout Offer | work=The Wall Street Journal | date=August 12, 2013 | accessdate=August 13, 2013}} The sale closed in October 2013, but was challenged by shareholders who argued that the company was undervalued, based in part on underestimated cost savings from the 2012 sale of the Asia business. In 2015, the [[Delaware Chancery Court]] awarded $148 million in damages to the former shareholders, on the grounds that Murdock and chief operating officer C. Michael Carter had misled shareholders regarding the finances of the company.{{cite news|last1=Hoffman|first1=Liz|title=Dole Executives Ordered to Pay $148 Million in Buyout Lawsuit|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/dole-executives-ordered-to-pay-148-million-in-buyout-lawsuit-1440686542|accessdate=2 September 2015|work=The Wall Street Journal|date=27 August 2015}} Dole, which had moved its corporate registration from Hawaii to Delaware in 2001, became an outspoken critic of Delaware corporate law as a result of this litigation.{{cite news|last1=Hoffman|first1=Liz|title=Dole and Other Companies Sour on Delaware as Corporate Haven|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/dole-and-other-companies-sour-on-delaware-as-corporate-haven-1438569507|accessdate=2 September 2015|work=The Wall Street Journal|date=2 August 2015}} ==Operations== Dole is a vertically integrated producer, owning plantations in Central America.{{cite web|last1=Wang|first1=Dan|title=Meet Dole, the World’s Full-Stack Banana Company|url=https://www.flexport.com/blog/why-dole-owns-container-ships/|publisher=Flexport|accessdate=5 January 2016}} It operates a fleet of 19 container ships{{cite web|title=Vessels|url=http://www.doleoceancargo.com/vessels.html|publisher=Dole Ocean Cargo|accessdate=5 January 2016}} that are specially equipped to support refrigerated containers and have their own cranes instead of relying on port infrastructure. ===Management=== In April 2017, Johan Linden was named [[Chief Executive Officer]], in addition to his role as President,{{cite web|title=Executive Profile: Johan Linden, Chief Executive Officer and President, Dole Food Company, Inc.|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=290561769&privcapId=259280&previousCapId=259280&previousTitle=Dole%20Food%20Company%20Inc.|publisher=Bloomberg|accessdate=31 January 2018|date=January 2018}} and Johan Malmqvist was [[Chief Financial Officer]].{{cite web|title=2017 Ranking of America's Largest Private Companies: Dole Food|url=https://www.forbes.com/companies/dole-food/|publisher=Forbes|accessdate=31 January 2018|date=2018}} ===Products=== [[File:Dolejf2103.JPG|thumb|220px|right|Fresh ripe Dole pineapples ([[Philippines]])]] Including the original [[pineapple]], Dole distributes fresh plant foods in the forms of whole fruits, whole vegetables, berries, and fresh-cut vegetables. Packaged products include fruit bowls, fruit bowls in gel, fruit in plastic jars, fruit parfaits, fruit crisps, dates, raisins, and canned fruits. Frozen products include berries, tropical fruits, and fruit bars. Juices are sold chilled, frozen, or canned. Salad products include greens, salad kits, and shreds.{{cite web |title= All About Dole Products |work= official web site |publisher= Dole Food, Inc |url= http://www.dole.com/EatRightLanding/EatRtProductIndex/tabid/892/Default.aspx |accessdate= September 15, 2010 }} In 1998 Dole bought several growers in [[Colombia]] and became the largest distributor of fresh-cut flowers in the US. However, by 2008 the flower business was losing money, and it was bought in January 2009 by a group of private investors. ===Corporate headquarters=== In 1994, Dole announced that it would finalize its plans to build its world headquarters on a {{convert|30|acre|m2|adj=on}} site owned by the company, located north of the [[Ventura Freeway]] in [[Westlake Village, California|Westlake Village]], California. The decision had been delayed by groundwater contamination tests and reviewing of possible site plan revisions. Having submitted its plans for final approval by the Westlake Village City Council on February 9, 1994,{{cite news |title= Dole gets ready to turn first shovel of headquarters dirt: plans are set to go to Westlake Village City Council |work= [[Los Angeles Business Journal]] |date= January 31, 1994 |url= http://www.allbusiness.com/north-america/united-states-california-metro-areas/426968-1.html |accessdate= September 15, 2010 }} Dole completed construction and opened its new world headquarters building in May 1999. ==Legacy== [[Image:Pineapple maze 1.JPG|thumb|Dole Plantation Pineapple Maze]] The [[Guinness Book of World Records]] (2001) lists the pineapple maze at the Dole Plantation in [[Oahu, Hawaii]] as the world's largest [[maze]].{{cite web|url=http://www.dole-plantation.com/Maze/maze.aspx |title=Dole Plantation - Hawaii's Complete Pineapple Experience - Maze |accessdate=2008-02-14 |publisher=Dole Plantation, Inc. |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080121014452/http://www.dole-plantation.com/Maze/maze.aspx |archivedate=2008-01-21 |deadurl=yes |df= }} The [[Dole Nutrition Institute]] (DNI) was founded by David H. Murdock in 2003 to "Feed the World with Knowledge" through research and education regarding the health benefits of a plant-based diet. ==Mascot== [[File:Dole Mascots (41848912380) (cropped).jpg|thumb|Bobby Banana and Pinellopy Pineapple in San Diego in 2018]] '''Bobby Banana''' is a [[mascot]] of Dole Food Company and the leader of the SuperKids (children who regularly eat five to nine fruits and vegetables every day).{{cite web|url=http://www.dole.com/WhatsASuperkid/tabid/824/Default.aspx |title=WhatsASuperkid |publisher=Dole |date= |accessdate=2012-10-05}} He is an [[anthropomorphism|anthropomorphic]] [[banana]] who appears in Dole comics and games for children, along with friends Courtney Cauliflower, Mia Mango, Pinellopy Pineapple, and Gavin Grape, all of whom are also anthropomorphic fruits and vegetables.{{cite web|url=http://www.dole.com/DoleFlashHomePage/tabid/972/Default.aspx#/superkids/ |title=Homepage |publisher=Dole |date=2010-06-21 |accessdate=2012-10-05}} In 1985 and 1986, the Dole banana was featured as the official banana of the Pittsburg State University (KS) Gorillas' athletic programs. The project was the brainchild of then Pitt State radiosports play-by-play voice Scott Burton. The introduction of the Dole banana as the official banana of the Gorillas delighted then Athletic Director David Suenram and Pittsburg State University sports fans alike. The head football coach at the time of the promotion was Dennis Franchione. Dole provided company trinkets for fan giveaways and the popularity of the Dole banana thrived in southeast Kansas and southwest Missouri (Joplin) during the promotion's two-year run. ==Advertising== For a number of years, the [[country music]] artist [[Kenny Rogers]] advertised Dole's products on television. He would often be accompanied by his then wife, Marianne. Dole also sponsored several of Rogers' concert tours. ==Food safety== ===2005 E. coli outbreak=== In 2005, 23 people in [[Minnesota]] were sickened with [[E. coli O157:H7]]. The source of the [[bacteria]] was found to be Dole brand bagged lettuce.{{cite web |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090208032833/http://www.producenews.com/storydetail.cfm?ID=5449 |archivedate=February 8, 2009 |url=http://www.producenews.com/storydetail.cfm?ID=5449 |title=Minnesota finds E. coli in lettuce bags |first=Joan |last=Murphy |location=Oradell, NJ, USA |work=The Produce News |issn=0032-969X|oclc=4109334|date=October 17, 2005 |accessdate=October 5, 2012|via=[[Wayback Machine]]}} ===2006 E. coli outbreak=== {{main|2006 North American E. coli O157:H7 outbreak in spinach}} In 2006, an E. coli outbreak that caused over 200 people to become ill and killed 3 more was linked to bagged [[spinach]] sold by Dole. The spinach was processed by Natural Selection Foods in [[California]].{{cite web|url=http://www.about-ecoli.com/ecoli_outbreaks/news/e-coli-found-in-water-wild-pig-near-california-spinach-farm/ |title=E. coli Food Poisoning |publisher=About-ecoli.com |date=2006-10-27 |accessdate=2012-10-05}} ===2007 E. coli recall=== In September 2007, random testing conducted by the [[Canadian Food Inspection Agency]] detected E. coli O157:H7 bacteria in Dole's "Hearts Delight" packaged salad. The company issued a recall for the product, which had been distributed in Ontario, Quebec, New Brunswick, Nova Scotia, and Prince Edward Island in Canada, and in Illinois, Indiana, Maine, Michigan, Mississippi, New York, Ohio, Pennsylvania, and Tennessee in the US.{{cite news|title=Dole Fresh Vegetables Announces Voluntary Recall of 'Dole Hearts Delight' Packaged Salads|first=Marty|last=Ordman|work=[[Food and Drug Administration]]|location=Silver Spring|accessdate=January 23, 2016|date=September 17, 2007|url=http://www.fda.gov/Safety/Recalls/ArchiveRecalls/2007/ucm112276.htm}} ===2012 Salmonella recall=== In April 2012, random testing by the [[New York State Department of Health]] detected Salmonella bacteria in Dole's "Seven Lettuces " salad. The company issued a recall for the product, which had been distributed in Alabama, Florida, Illinois, Indiana, Maryland, Massachusetts, Michigan, Mississippi, New York, North Carolina, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Tennessee, Virginia and Wisconsin.{{cite news|work=[[Food Safety News]]|url=http://www.foodsafetynews.com/2016/05/publishers-platform-will-the-justice-department-look-at-doles-history-of-recalls-and-outbreaks/|title=Will the Justice Department look at Dole's history of recalls and outbreaks?|date=May 2, 2016|accessdate=May 3, 2016|first=Bill|last=Marler|authorlink=William Marler}} ===June 2012 Listeria recall=== In June 2012, random testing by the [[North Carolina Department of Health and Human Services]] detected [[Listeria monocytogenes]], the bacteria responsible for [[listeriosis]], in Dole's "Marketside Leafy Romaine" salad. The company issued a recall for the product, which had been distributed in Georgia, Kentucky, North Carolina, South Carolina, Tennessee and Virginia. ===August 2012 Listeria recall=== In August 2012, random testing by the North Carolina Department of Agriculture detected Listeria monocytogenes in Dole's packaged "Italian Blend" salad. The company issued a recall for the product, which had been distributed in Alabama, Florida, North Carolina, South Carolina, Pennsylvania, Maryland, Mississippi and Virginia. ===2014 Listeria recall=== In March 2014, random testing conducted by the Canadian Food Inspection Agency detected Listeria monocytogenes in Dole's packaged "Italian Blend" salad.{{cite news|title=Dole Brand Salad Recalled in Canada Due to Potential Listeria Contamination|date=March 13, 2014|work=[[Food Safety News]]|location=Seattle|url=http://www.foodsafetynews.com/2014/03/dole-brand-salad-recalled-due-to-potential-listeria-contamination/#.UyN0DfldWAY|accessdate=January 24, 2014}} The company issued a recall for its Dole Italian Blend, Fresh Selections Italian Style Blend, Little Salad Bar Italian Salad, and Marketside Italian Style Salad products. The products had been distributed in Ontario, Quebec and New Brunswick in Canada, and Connecticut, Florida, Illinois, Indiana, Kentucky, Maryland, Massachusetts, Michigan, New Jersey, New York, North Carolina, Ohio, Pennsylvania, South Carolina and Virginia in the US.{{cite news|title=Dole Expands Bagged Salad Recall to the U.S. Over Listeria Concerns|date=March 14, 2014|work=[[Food Safety News]]|location=Seattle|url=http://www.foodsafetynews.com/2014/03/dole-expands-bagged-salad-recall-to-the-u-s-due-to-listeria/|accessdate=January 24, 2016}} ===2015 Salmonella recall=== In October 2015, random testing conducted by the [[Michigan Department of Agriculture and Rural Development]] detected [[Salmonella]] bacteria in a sample of Dole's packaged spinach salad. The company issued a recall for the product, which had been distributed to Connecticut, Indiana, Kentucky, Maryland, Massachusetts, Michigan, Missouri, New Jersey, New York, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Tennessee, and Wisconsin.{{cite news|title=Dole Fresh Vegetables Announces Precautionary Recall of Limited Number of Spinach Salads|date=October 13, 2015|work=[[Food and Drug Administration]]|location=Silver Spring|first=Bill|last=Goldfield}} ===2016 Listeriosis outbreak=== In January 2016, packaged salads produced by Dole at its Springfield, Ohio, facility were linked to a multistate outbreak of listeriosis by the [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]] (CDC).{{cite news|title=Multistate Outbreak of Listeriosis Linked to Packaged Salads Produced at Springfield, Ohio Dole Processing Facility|date=January 22, 2016|work=[[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]]|location=Atlanta|url=https://www.cdc.gov/listeria/outbreaks/bagged-salads-01-16/index.html|accessdate=January 23, 2013}} The outbreak was first detected in July 2015 and led to the hospitalization of 12 people from Indiana, Massachusetts, Michigan, New Jersey, New York, and Pennsylvania.{{cite news|title=1 dead, 11 others hospitalized in listeria outbreak linked to Dole salads|first=Liz|last=Szabo|work=[[USA Today]]|location=Tysons Corner|date=January 22, 2016|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/2016/01/22/deadly-listeria-outbreak-puts-12-people-hospital/79175942/|accessdate=January 23, 2016}} The victim from Michigan died as a result of the infection.{{cite news|title=Listeria Outbreak Linked to Dole Salads From Ohio Facility|first1=Jesse|last1=Newman|first2=Ilan|last2=Brat|date=January 22, 2016|work=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|location=New York City|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/cdc-links-listeria-outbreak-to-dole-foods-ohio-facility-1453493700|accessdate=January 23, 2016}} A joint CDC and [[Food and Drug Administration]] (FDA) investigation began in September 2015. In January 2016, testing of a Dole "Field Greens" packaged salad found the presence of Listeria monocytogenes, the bacteria responsible for listeriosis.{{cite news|title=Listeria Outbreak Linked to Dole’s Packaged Salads|first=Alexandra|last=Sifferlin|date=January 22, 2016|url=http://time.com/4190945/listeria-outbreak-dole-packaged-salads/|work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|location=New York City|accessdate=January 23, 2016}} On January 21, 2016, Dole suspended operations at the Springfield facility and began a recall of packaged salads produced there. The recall affected 23 states and 3 Canadian provinces, and involved salads packaged under the Dole, Fresh Selections, Simple Truth, Marketside, The Little Salad Bar, and President's Choice brand names.{{cite news|date=January 22, 2016|title=Food Recall Warning: Certain Dole brand pre-packaged chopped salads, salad blends and kits and leafy greens and certain PC Organics brand leafy greens recalled due to Listeria monocytogenes|work=[[Canadian Food Inspection Agency]]|location=Ottawa|url=http://www.inspection.gc.ca/about-the-cfia/newsroom/food-recall-warnings/complete-listing/2016-01-22c/eng/1453522915084/1453522920123|accessdate=January 24, 2016}}{{cite news|title=Dole Fresh Vegetables Announces a Voluntary Withdrawal of Salads Processed at its Springfield OH Processing Facility|work=Dole Food Company|location=Westlake Village|date=January 22, 2016|url=http://www.dole.com/en/about/withdrawal|accessdate=January 23, 2016}} In April 2016, it was revealed that the [[United States Department of Justice|U.S. Department of Justice]] had commenced a criminal investigation into Dole's role in the outbreak of listeriosis.{{cite news|work=[[Food Safety News]]|title=Dole knew of Listeria; feds launch criminal investigation|first=Coral|last=Beach|date=April 29, 2016|url=http://www.foodsafetynews.com/2016/04/fda-report-shows-dole-officials-knew-about-listeria-in-facility/#.VyOJBmNEz_Q|accessdate=April 30, 2016}} FDA inspection reports obtained by ''[[Food Safety News]]'' using the [[Freedom of Information Act (United States)|Freedom of Information Act]] demonstrated that in July 2014 Dole carried out swab tests of surfaces in the Springfield plant which returned positive results for Listeria but still did not cease production. Swab tests returned positive results "five more times in 2014 and three times in late 2015" but Dole continued production until January 2016. [[United States House of Representatives|U.S. Reprepresentative]] [[Rosa DeLauro]] said: "News that Dole knew about a Listeria outbreak in their facility, yet continued to push contaminated salads onto the American consumer is an outrage. How could executives at Dole even consider putting products onto store shelves and into American homes when they knew for close to two years that there was a major public health issue? These executives must be held accountable for their unconscionable actions."{{cite news|title=DeLauro Demands That Dole Answer For Distributing Contaminated Salads That Killed Americans|work=[[United States House of Representatives]]|location=Washington, DC|date=April 29, 2016|url=http://delauro.house.gov/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=2288:delauro-demands-that-dole-answer-for-distributing-contaminated-salads-that-killed-americans&catid=2&Itemid=21#pq=9KHoVR|accessdate=May 2, 2016}}{{cite news|title=Dole salad scandal spurs calls for stronger FDA|first=Coral|last=Beach|date=April 30, 2016|work=[[Food Safety News]]|url=http://www.foodsafetynews.com/2016/04/125871/|accessdate=May 2, 2016}} ==Criticism and controversies== ===Legal cases=== In 2001, Dole was involved in the suit [[Del Monte Fresh Produce Co. v. Dole Food Co.]] with Del Monte Fresh over the potential misappropriation of Del Monte's specially bred pineapple. ===Hawaiian coup=== {{main|Overthrow of the Kingdom of Hawaii}} [[James Dole]], who founded the [[Hawaiian Pineapple Company]], went to Hawaii in 1899, five years after his cousin (once removed), [[Sanford B. Dole]] had become first president of the republic, following the overthrow of the Hawaiian monarchy.{{citation |url= http://the.honoluluadvertiser.com/150/sesq2dole |title=James Dole |first=Michael |last=Tsai |work=[[The Honolulu Advertiser]] |publisher=[[Black Press]] |location=Honolulu, HI, USA |date=July 2, 2006 |accessdate=October 4, 2012}} Although his elder cousin was involved with the takeover of Hawaii, James himself was a teenager living in Massachusetts at the time of the coup.{{cite book |title= Men of Hawaii: a biographical reference library, complete and authentic, of the men of note and substantial achievement in the Hawaiian Islands |publisher=[[Honolulu Star-Bulletin]] |location=Honolulu, HI, USA|year=1921 | editor-last=Siddall |editor-first=John William |volume=2 |series=The Story of Hawaii and its builders |id={{OCLC|80553001|32127632|16326675}} |lccn= 22017988 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4o8DAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA133 |page= 133 |accessdate=October 4, 2012}} However, the company's commercial activities would not have been possible without the later annexation of Hawaii to the US,{{Citation |last=Okihiro |first=Gary Y |author-link=Gary Okihiro |year=2009 |title=Pineapple culture : a history of the tropical and temperate zones |chapter=Hawaiian Pine |series=The California world history library |volume=10 |publisher=[[University of California Press]] |publication-place=Berkeley, CA, USA |page=130 |isbn=9780520265905 |oclc=449860318}} which resulted in the removal of high import tariffs on Hawaiian products. {{cite book |title=Overthrow: America's Century of Regime Change from Hawaii to Iraq |title-link=Overthrow (book) |last=Kinzer |first=Stephen |author-link=Kinzer, Stephen |publisher=[[Times Books]] |isbn=0-8050-7861-4 }} Removal of tariffs through annexation was one of the goals of the 1894 coup plotters, though annexation did not occur until 1898.{{Citation |last=Furnas |first=J. C. |author-link=J. C. Furnas |others=[[Institute of Pacific Relations]], American Council |year=1948 |origyear=1937 |title= Anatomy of paradise : Hawaii and the islands of the South Seas |chapter=Land of Makebelieve Come True |publisher=William Sloane Associates |publication-place=New York, NY, USA |pages=173–183 |id={{OCLC|577040553|183094599|8278107}} |url=http://hdl.handle.net/2027/uc1.b3378160?urlappend=%3Bseq=191 |accessdate=October 4, 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://archive.org/stream/anatomyofparadis012497mbp |archivedate=November 1, 2006}} ===Labor relations=== [[File:004 Dole company, banana fruit sticker.jpg|thumb|220px|right|Dole banana fruit label]] The [[banana industry]] has traditionally been dominated by a few large corporations, which employ [[low-wage work]]ers in [[developing countries]].{{cite book |author=Peter Chapman |title=Bananas: How the United Fruit Company Shaped the World |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uQdHiU4lodAC&pg=PA21 |date=July 2009 |publisher=Canongate U.S. |isbn=978-1-84767-194-3 |page=21}}{{cite web |title= The Banana Trade War |work= Global Issues Blog |author= Anup Shah |date= January 3, 2010 |url= http://www.globalissues.org/article/63/the-banana-trade-war |accessdate= September 15, 2010 }} Dole was named as a defendant in a wrongful death lawsuit filed on behalf of 73 heirs of victims of paramilitary violence in Colombia.{{cite web |title= Juana Perez 1-51/Juan Perez 5E-50 v. Dole Food Company, Inc. |publisher= International Rights Advocates |work= Cases |date= April 2009 |url= http://www.iradvocates.org/dolecase.html |accessdate= 2010-01-20 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100523100708/http://www.iradvocates.org/dolecase.html |archivedate= 2010-05-23 |df= }} In 2007, [[Nicaragua]]n [[banana plantation|plantation]] workers, represented by [[Los Angeles]]-based [[personal injury]] [[lawyer]] [[Juan Dominguez (lawyer)|Juan Dominguez]], sued Dole and [[Dow Chemical Company]], claiming the use of illegal pesticides such as the now banned [[1,2-Dibromo-3-chloropropane|Nemagon]] (containing DBCP) had made them [[Infertility|sterile]]. The pesticide was not banned in Nicaragua until after Dole ceased its operations within the country. The suit and two others were subsequently thrown out by California courts after it was concluded that “[c]ontrary to their sworn testimony, most of the plaintiffs never worked on Dole-affiliated banana farms and none were involved in the DBCP application process,” while similar lawsuits were filed in U.S. and Nicaraguan courts.{{cite news| url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601109&sid=aS5ED.ApmVPk | work=Bloomberg | title=Dole Uses Judge Attack in Banana Case to Undo $2 Billion Awards | date=June 24, 2009}} A lawyer for the Nicaraguans, Steve Condie, however, alleged that some of the witnesses had been paid by Dole to give testimony that the claims were fraudulent. The witnesses' identities were kept secret so that the plaintiffs' lawyers could not interview them. Swedish film director [[Fredrik Gertten]] made a documentary film about Dominguez and the alleged banana workers. The movie ''[[Bananas!*]]'' premiered in the 2009 [[Los Angeles Film Festival]]. Dole said they had serious concerns about the film's accuracy and they urged festival officials to "immediately cease and desist" their sponsorship of the film.{{cite web |url=http://www.bananasthemovie.com/wp-content/uploads/resources/letter_from_dole_may8_09.pdf |title=Letter from Dole, May 8, 2009 |first=Scott A.|last=Edelman |work=bananasthemovie.com |date=May 8, 2009 |accessdate=October 6, 2012}}{{cite web|url=http://www.bananasthemovie.com/interview-with-director-fredrik-gertten/ |title=Interview with director Fredrik Gertten | BANANAS!* |publisher=Bananasthemovie.com |date= |accessdate=2012-10-05}}{{cite web |url=http://svt.se/2.33782/1.1591791/bananas_far_inte_tavla_pa_festival |title=Bananas får inte tävla på festival - Regionala nyheter |publisher=svt.se |date= |accessdate=2012-10-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121006015213/http://www.svt.se/2.33782/1.1591791/bananas_far_inte_tavla_pa_festival |archivedate=2012-10-06 |df= }}{{cite web|title=About the film – BANANAS!*|url=http://www.bananasthemovie.com/about-the-film/#article}} 11 June 2009 - bananasthemovie.com The festival officials allowed the film to be screened, but it was not allowed to compete for placement in the competition. In addition, festival officials distributed information before the film's screening that indicated Dole believed the film to be factually inaccurate. Although the film was screened with a disclaimer from the festival, Gertten was subsequently sued for defamation by Dole.{{cite news |url=http://seattletimes.com/html/businesstechnology/2009346592_apusdolebananaworkers.html |title=Dole sues 'Bananas!' filmmaker, alleges defamation |first=Linda |last=Deutcsh |agency=[[Associated Press]] |newspaper=[[The Seattle Times]] |date=July 9, 2009 |publisher=[[The Seattle Times Company]] |location=Seattle, WA, USA |accessdate=October 4, 2012}} The lawsuit was dropped on October 15, 2009, and in November 2010 a court in Los Angeles found in favour of the movie crew making it possible to release the movie in the USA, and ordering Dole to pay SEK 1.4 million (roughly USD 200,000) to the filmmakers.{{cite web|url=http://www.dn.se/kultur-noje/film-tv/-filmen-bananas-vann-mot-dole |title=Filmen "Bananas" vann mot Dole |trans-title=The film "Bananas" won against Dole |language=Swedish |first=Nora |last=Mlik |publisher=Dn.se |location=Stockholm, Sweden |accessdate=October 6, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130116171719/http://www.dn.se/kultur-noje/film-tv/-filmen-bananas-vann-mot-dole |archivedate=January 16, 2013 |df= }} {{Google translation|en|sv|http://www.dn.se/kultur-noje/film-tv/-filmen-bananas-vann-mot-dole|Google machine translation of this article}} Gertten's sequel ''[[Big Boys Gone Bananas!*]]'' documents Dole's reactions to ''Bananas!*''. The Nicaraguan DBCP awards against Dole were overturned in July 2010.{{cite news |title= Judge throws out verdict awarding millions to Dole workers |newspaper= [[Los Angeles Times]] |author= Victoria Kim |date= July 16, 2010 |url= http://articles.latimes.com/2010/jul/16/local/la-me-dole-20100716 |accessdate= September 15, 2010 }} In May 2013 [[Oxfam]] demanded Dole remove its "Ethical Choice" labels from its bananas in New Zealand until it improved treatment of its workers in [[the Philippines]], but Dole said Oxfam was trying to "destroy the Dole brand" in favour of other suppliers.{{cite news| url= http://www.3news.co.nz/Dole-bananas-not-ethical---Oxfam/tabid/1160/articleID/299404/Default.aspx |work=3 News NZ |title= Dole bananas not ethical - Oxfam| date=May 28, 2013}} In Oct 2018 Myanmar Government blacklisted Thailand subsidiary of Dole after investigation found that one of its factory in Thailand exploited Myanmar migrant workers by demanding payments for visas, medical check-ups and work permit fees. Myanmar migrant workers are also prevented from taking paid annual leave. About 130 Myanmar migrants who took annual leaves were prevented from returning to work and got fired instead.{{cite news| url= https://www.mmtimes.com/news/govt-blacklists-dole-thailand-over-labour-dispute.html |work=MyanmarTimes MM |title= Govt blacklists Dole-Thailand over labour dispute| date=Oct 10, 2018}} ===Labeling of genetically engineered foods in California=== In 2012, Dole Packaged Foods contributed $171,261 to a $46 million political campaign known as "The Coalition Against The Costly Food Labeling Proposition, sponsored by Farmers and Food Producers".{{cite web|url=http://www.kcet.org/news/ballotbrief/elections2012/propositions/prop-37-funding-genetically-engineered-food.html |title=Who's Funding Prop 37, Labeling for Genetically Engineered Foods? | Propositions | Elections 2012 |publisher=KCET.org |date= |accessdate=2015-06-06}} ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== {{Commons category}} {{Portal|Hawaii|Los Angeles|Food|Companies}} * {{Official website|www.dole.com}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120214183130/http://biz.yahoo.com/ic/10/10303.html Yahoo! - Dole Food Company, Inc. Company Profile] {{Dole Food Company}} {{Pineapples}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:Dole Food Company| ]] [[Category:Agriculture companies of the United States]] [[Category:Food manufacturers of the United States]] [[Category:Multinational food companies]] [[Category:Multinational companies headquartered in the United States]] [[Category:Pineapple production]] [[Category:Business in Hawaii]] [[Category:Companies based in Hawaii]] [[Category:Companies based in Westlake Village, California]] [[Category:Westlake Village, California]] [[Category:American companies established in 1851]] [[Category:Food and drink companies established in 1851]] [[Category:1851 establishments in Hawaii]] [[Category:Companies formerly listed on the New York Stock Exchange]] [[Category:Banana production]] [[Category:Fruit production]] [[Category:2013 mergers and acquisitions]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2018}} {{Use British English|date=April 2018}} '''Edwin Ellis (Ed) Tozer''' (born 1943) is a British retired management and IT consultant and [[SF author]],[https://www.amazon.com/Ed-Tozer/e/B003E0ZUGW Ed Tozer] at amazon.com. Accessed 9 May 2015. particularly known for his early work on business information systems in the 1970s and 1980s.Andriole, Stephen J. "The collaborate/integrate business technology strategy." Communications of the ACM 49.5 (2006): 85-90.{{cite journal | last1 = Peña-Mora | first1 = Feniosky | last2 = Tanaka | first2 = Shunsuke | year = 2002 | title = Information technology planning framework for Japanese general contractors | url = | journal = Journal of Management in Engineering | volume = 18 | issue = 3| pages = 138–149 | doi=10.1061/(asce)0742-597x(2002)18:3(138)}} == Life and work == Tozer started his career in the manufacturing and mining industry.Tozer (1986); {{cite journal | url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/0024630186902670 | doi=10.1016/0024-6301(86)90267-0 | volume=19 | title=Developing strategies for management information systems | journal=Long Range Planning | pages=31–40}} In 1969 he became junior systems analyst at the management consultancy firm Scicon in London; a subsidiary of British Petroleum, originally known as Scientific Control Systems, chaired by Sir [[Maurice Kendall]]. After spells with other consulting firms, he worked with [[James Martin (author)|James Martin]]'s European operation from 1982 to 1984. In 1984 he founded Edwin E. Tozer Limited, specialized in data management study, which he dissolved after his retirement in 2008."[https://www.duedil.com/company/01791018/edwin-e-tozer-limited Edwin E. Tozer Limited]," at duedil.com. Accessed 23-03-2015. In 1984 he published his first book, entitled "Application Development Tools." in 1988 his second book, "Planning for effective business Information systems," and in 1996 his third book, entitled "Strategic Is/It Planning." Since his retirement in the new millennium he has been writing SF literature. == Work == In the 1970s Tozer became involved in the [[CODASYL]] development of database languages, and wrote his first articles on databases and systems analysis and design{{DBLP |name=E. E. Tozer}} He specialized in "effective application of Information Technology to business and administrative problems."Tozer (1975) === ''Database Systems Analysis and Design,'' 1976 === In the 1976 article "Database Systems Analysis and Design," Tozer made a comparison between the database field and the evolving field of the Programming technology. He argued:
Developments in the database field have tended to emphasise programming technology, with a dearth of accompanying progress in systems analysis and design methods. This paper puts forward an overall view of system design which is intended to act as a constraining framework. It is based upon a pragmatic approach and is presented in a form which could be (and is being) used on large scale implementation projects.Tozer (1976)
And furthermore:
Orderly analysis and design procedures are encouraged. The taking of premature design decisions is discouraged, especially through the recognition of three distinct views of data: conceptual, implementation and storage, and through recognition of distinctions between design of each of these, specification of mappings between them, and design of programs and run sequences. It is envisaged that specific procedures developed elsewhere (see references) could be incorporated into the methodology described here.
=== ''Developing strategies for management information systems,'' 1986 === {{see also|History of business architecture}} In the 1989 article "Developing strategies for management information systems," Tozer presented a model for developing information systems. Tozer's approach was based on his experience of "planning projects in a variety of industries, including wholesale and retail banking, consumer credit, chemicals, Multinational manufacturing and distribution and the oil industry."Tozer (1986) Tozer presented a model, which consisted of the following four phases:
* ''Phase 1:'' Determine business information needs: This results from the analysis of a series of senior management interviews which are conducted according to a predefined format. The analysis goes through the stages of functional objectives, critical success factors, control information and other quantitative means for determining the successful achievement of critical success factors, leading to a definition of specific information needs. * ''Phase 2:'' Development of conceptual architecture for systems and data: This phase produces clear architecture statements for application systems and associated conceptual database... * ''Phase 3:'' Determine key priorities and system groupings... * ''Phase 4:'' Migration plane. The final sets of deliverables are the plans for achieving the business and technical systems as outlined in these architectures...
The key features of this model, according to Azad (1990) were:
# [ït] starts with business planning process dealing with logical links and dependencies on corporate and divisional plans. #Is pragmatic and hence practical. #Combines formality and business expediency. #Takes account of trends in business and information planning. #Encourages the active use of up to date approach in the development if information systems utilising the fourth generation language by the user. #Follows through into the development of a complete, practical, business orientated information system dealing with what must be done, how long it takes, and how much it is going to cost. #Is open with regard to extension and enhancement. #Has been used successfully in major corporations, continues to be used and hence is continuing to develop further.Farsheed Azad. "MSc. Information Engineering: An investigation on models and methodologies for developing an I.S. Stratey," June 1990. at pchelpline.com, uploaded 2012/07. Accessed 23-03-2015
In this 1986 paper Tozer was one of the first to propose the concept of [[business architecture]] in the field of business information systems planning. === ''Planning for effective business Information systems,'' 1988 === In his 1988 ''Planning for effective business Information systems,'' Tozer developed a particular view on [[Enterprise Data Planning]], that dealt with the complexities of extracting key business needs from senior management and then defining relevant architectural visions for the specific enterprise. In the early 1980s [[James Martin (author)|James Martin]] had been one of the pathfinders in data planning methodologies. He was one of the first to identify data as being an enterprise wide asset that required management, and had developed a series of tools and methods to support that process.[[James Martin (author)|James Martin]]. ''Viewdata and the information society.'' 1982 Most of the large consulting firms developed their own methods to address the same basic issue. Frequently, their approaches were incorporated into their own branded system development methodologies that encompassed the complete systems development life-cycle. === ''Strategic IS/IT Planning,'' 1996 === Tozer's "Strategic IS/IT Planning", was published in 1996 by Butterworth Heinemann as part of the Datamation Professional Series. The book mentioned to offer:
* Supports a range of business planning techniques such as Portfolio Management and Value Chain Analysis. * Helps to ensure accurate and continuing aligning of IS/IT strategy with business goals and intentions. * Delivers a complete IS/IT plan, integrated with the business planning process, with effective provision for implementation and continuing maintenance. * Incorporates the latest advances in information technology, including Open Systems and Client/Server.Tozer (1998)
The book was the most comprehensive outline of Tozer's approaches, though it now appears very dated; for example because it didn't even mention the [[Internet]]. === ''Morphosis,'' 2010 === In his 2010 [[science fiction]] novel "Morphosis," Tozer has been "speculating that mankind as an evolving species may still be in an early, vulnerable, fledgling state, as much at risk from itself as from environmental factors and competition from other species... [and] sometimes wonders whether it may be necessary - albeit difficult - for us as a species to shed some of the attributes and ingrained reflexes such as our tendency to violent conflict which we developed during our evolutionary struggle for survival so far before we can hope to reach our destiny as a mature species on the wider stage." == Selected publications == * Tozer, Edwin E. ''Application Development Tools.'' Elsevier Science Inc., 1984. * E. E. Tozer. ''Planning for effective business Information systems,'' 1988 * E. E. Tozer. ''Strategic Is/It Planning.'' 1996. * Ed Tozer. ''Morphosis,'' 2010. Articles, a selection: * D. A. Hawley, J. S. Knowles, E. E. Tozer. "[http://comjnl.oxfordjournals.org/content/18/3/206.full.pdf+html?sid=d58ebe33-7a2f-451e-9dae-78667ac74c61 Database Consistency and the CODASYL DBTG Proposals]." ''Comput. J.'' 18(3): 206-212 (1975) * {{cite journal | last1 = Tozer | first1 = E. E. | year = | title = Database Systems Analysis and Design | url = | journal = ECI | volume = 1976 | issue = | pages = 193–224 }} * E. E. Tozer. "Database Design Experience." ''ER'' 1979: 623-624 * {{cite journal | last1 = Tozer | first1 = Edwin E | year = 1986 | title = Developing strategies for management information systems | url = | journal = Long Range Planning | volume = 19 | issue = 4| pages = 31–40 | doi=10.1016/0024-6301(86)90267-0}} * {{cite journal | last1 = Tozer | first1 = Edwin E | year = 1986 | title = Developing plans for information systems | url = | journal = Long Range Planning | volume = 19 | issue = 5| pages = 63–75 | doi=10.1016/0024-6301(86)90010-5}} == References == {{reflist|2}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Tozer, Edwin Ellis}} [[Category:1943 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:British business theorists]] [[Category:British software engineers]] [[Category:British management consultants]]
